elements.content: Herein, we present a detailed X-ray charge density study of the electron delocalization in five species of chloranilic acid: neutral molecule, mono- and dianion, and two chelating modes: bidendate and (bis)­bidentate. The experiments provide the electron density at the bond critical points, which yields an accurate measure of bond order (and therefore electron delocalization), and complement previous literature and our data on bond lengths extracted from crystal structures and infrared spectra. Mapping of the electrostatic potential indicates electron-rich and electron-poor areas in the molecule, corresponding to single (electron-poor), double, and delocalized bonds (electron-rich) that can explain stacking interactions of quinoid rings in crystal packing.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present a detailed X-ray charge density study of the electron delocalization in five species of chloranilic acid: neutral molecule, mono- and dianion, and two chelating modes: bidendate and (bis)bidentate. The experiments provide the electron density at the bond critical points, which yields an accurate measure of bond order (and therefore electron delocalization), and complement previous literature and our data on bond lengths extracted from crystal structures and infrared spectra. Mapping of the electrostatic potential indicates electron-rich and electron-poor areas in the molecule, corresponding to single (electron-poor), double, and delocalized bonds (electron-rich) that can explain stacking interactions of quinoid rings in crystal packing.

elements.content: Electronic structure of five species of chloranilic acid (neutral molecule, mono- and dianion, and two chelating modes: bidendate and (bis)­bidentate) is determined by X-ray charge density studies. Electron density at the bond critical points yields an accurate measure of bond order and therefore electron delocalization. The π-electron system of chloranilic acid is especially malleable, so it can adopt various degrees of delocalization, depending on the ionization and molecular environment.
elements.clean_text: Electronic structure of five species of chloranilic acid (neutral molecule, mono- and dianion, and two chelating modes: bidendate and (bis)bidentate) is determined by X-ray charge density studies. Electron density at the bond critical points yields an accurate measure of bond order and therefore electron delocalization. The π-electron system of chloranilic acid is especially malleable, so it can adopt various degrees of delocalization, depending on the ionization and molecular environment.

elements.content: Motivation for an extensive investigation of the electronic structure of chloranilic acid, 3,6-dichloro-2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-quinone (H2CA), as a member of a well-known group of substituted 2,5-dihydroxyquinones has been found in its versatile chemical properties. It was first prepared in 1891 by Graebe. Its OH groups are easily deprotonated due to an inductive effect of the electronegative chlorine substituents stabilizing the anion. Chloranilic acid is therefore an acid of moderate strength with pK a values of 0.73 and 3.08. It is a quinoid compound with very diverse chemical behavior: it is a good metal ligand, proton donor and acceptor, and it is prone to strong stacking interactions. Versatility of its functions originates from a highly malleable π electron system, which can adopt various degrees of delocalization, depending on the ionization and molecular environment. The neutral form of chloranilic acid () is a typical para-quinone, while its dianion form reveals two delocalized 1-oxo-3-hydroxyallyl-like systems joined together in a six-membered ring by two single C–C bonds. The mono anion, however, has a delocalized system over one-half of the ring, while the other half has distinguishable single and double bonds. It can also bind to metals either as a bridging (bis)­bidentate ligand, which has a dianion-like structure, or as a terminal bidentate ligand with an ortho-quinoid structure ().
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Motivation for an extensive investigation of the electronic structure of chloranilic acid, 3,6-dichloro-2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-quinone (H2CA), as a member of a well-known group of substituted 2,5-dihydroxyquinones has been found in its versatile chemical properties. It was first prepared in 1891 by Graebe. Its OH groups are easily deprotonated due to an inductive effect of the electronegative chlorine substituents stabilizing the anion. Chloranilic acid is therefore an acid of moderate strength with pK a values of 0.73 and 3.08. It is a quinoid compound with very diverse chemical behavior: it is a good metal ligand, proton donor and acceptor, and it is prone to strong stacking interactions. Versatility of its functions originates from a highly malleable π electron system, which can adopt various degrees of delocalization, depending on the ionization and molecular environment. The neutral form of chloranilic acid () is a typical para-quinone, while its dianion form reveals two delocalized 1-oxo-3-hydroxyallyl-like systems joined together in a six-membered ring by two single C-C bonds. The mono anion, however, has a delocalized system over one-half of the ring, while the other half has distinguishable single and double bonds. It can also bind to metals either as a bridging (bis)bidentate ligand, which has a dianion-like structure, or as a terminal bidentate ligand with an ortho-quinoid structure ().

elements.clean_text: 1  Most Common Species of Chloranilic Acid (I) and Its Anions (II and III) Capable of Forming Metal and Organic Salts and Metal Complexes (IV and V)

elements.content: Differences in molecular geometry, related to changes in the electronic structure, significantly affect infrared (IR) spectra: C–C and C–O stretching bands display a variety of red- and blue-shifts. Like other 2,5-dihydroxyquinones, it is a versatile ligand toward transition metals and behaves similarly to oxalate. A variety of chloranilate complexes are known with topologies ranging from discrete mono- and binuclear units, one-dimensional (1D) linear and zigzag polymers, two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) networks. The most common coordination modes are bridging (bis)­bidentate and terminal bidentate. Their topologies affect magnetic exchange interactions.
elements.clean_text: Differences in molecular geometry, related to changes in the electronic structure, significantly affect infrared (IR) spectra: C-C and C-O stretching bands display a variety of red- and blue-shifts. Like other 2,5-dihydroxyquinones, it is a versatile ligand toward transition metals and behaves similarly to oxalate. A variety of chloranilate complexes are known with topologies ranging from discrete mono- and binuclear units, one-dimensional (1D) linear and zigzag polymers, two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) networks. The most common coordination modes are bridging (bis)bidentate and terminal bidentate. Their topologies affect magnetic exchange interactions.

elements.content: Chloranilic acid also readily forms salts and cocrystals with alkali and organic cations involving a proton transfer. These properties of chloranilic acid have been widely used in analytical procedures exemplified by visible spectrophotometric determination of various pharmaceuticals, such as valsartan (blocking the action of angiotensin and dilating blood vessels manifested by reduced blood pressure). Determination of metals using complexation ability of chloranilic acid in adsorption stripping voltammetry for metal traces has been exploited: detection of uranium traces in nuclear reactor IEA-R1 pool water and for sensitive quantification Ge (IV).
elements.clean_text: Chloranilic acid also readily forms salts and cocrystals with alkali and organic cations involving a proton transfer. These properties of chloranilic acid have been widely used in analytical procedures exemplified by visible spectrophotometric determination of various pharmaceuticals, such as valsartan (blocking the action of angiotensin and dilating blood vessels manifested by reduced blood pressure). Determination of metals using complexation ability of chloranilic acid in adsorption stripping voltammetry for metal traces has been exploited: detection of uranium traces in nuclear reactor IEA-R1 pool water and for sensitive quantification Ge (IV).

elements.content: Chloranilic acid is a strong donor and acceptor of hydrogen bonds and also possesses an unusual propensity for cycle stacking. While chloranilate dianions stack similarly to aromatic rings, hydrogen chloranilate monoanions and neutral molecules are able to form unprecedented face-to-face stacks with very short interplanar distances (∼3.3 Å). Energy of these close interactions is comparable to medium-strong hydrogen bonds, exhibiting potential for crystal engineering. Similar stacks are observed in analogous compounds such as bromanilic acid and unsubstituted 2,5-dihydroxyquinone.
elements.clean_text: Chloranilic acid is a strong donor and acceptor of hydrogen bonds and also possesses an unusual propensity for cycle stacking. While chloranilate dianions stack similarly to aromatic rings, hydrogen chloranilate monoanions and neutral molecules are able to form unprecedented face-to-face stacks with very short interplanar distances (~3.3 Å). Energy of these close interactions is comparable to medium-strong hydrogen bonds, exhibiting potential for crystal engineering. Similar stacks are observed in analogous compounds such as bromanilic acid and unsubstituted 2,5-dihydroxyquinone.

elements.content: Electronic structure of chloranilic acid, particularly delocalization of π electrons, changes significantly upon (de)­protonation and complexation of transition metals (), affecting molecular geometries. These changes are documented by corresponding IR spectra: neutral molecule (p-quinoid ring) and terminal bidentate chloranilate ligand (o-quinone) have two C–O stretching bands, close to single and double bonds, whereas in dianions and bridging (bis)­bidentate chloranilate ligands, only one C–O stretch is observed, corresponding to a delocalized bond. Recent X-ray charge density studies of potassium hydrogen chloranilate dihydrate and a series of lutidinium chloranilates confirmed the electronic structure of its monoanion and dianion forms (, forms II and III). Variability of electronic structure of chloranilic acid and its anions prompted us to a detailed X-ray charge density study of its species (). Here, we present structures of neutral and metal chelating species (, forms I, IV, V) and compare them to monoanion and dianion species (, forms II and III, this work and ref ).
elements.clean_text: Electronic structure of chloranilic acid, particularly delocalization of π electrons, changes significantly upon (de)protonation and complexation of transition metals (), affecting molecular geometries. These changes are documented by corresponding IR spectra: neutral molecule (p-quinoid ring) and terminal bidentate chloranilate ligand (o-quinone) have two C-O stretching bands, close to single and double bonds, whereas in dianions and bridging (bis)bidentate chloranilate ligands, only one C-O stretch is observed, corresponding to a delocalized bond. Recent X-ray charge density studies of potassium hydrogen chloranilate dihydrate and a series of lutidinium chloranilates confirmed the electronic structure of its monoanion and dianion forms (, forms II and III). Variability of electronic structure of chloranilic acid and its anions prompted us to a detailed X-ray charge density study of its species (). Here, we present structures of neutral and metal chelating species (, forms I, IV, V) and compare them to monoanion and dianion species (, forms II  and III, this work and ref ).

elements.content: To minimize problems with X-ray absorption, we carefully selected compounds that readily grow well-developed crystals, comprise atoms as light as possible, and have as small asymmetric units as possible. To emphasize the difference in electron delocalization, we will use the atom numbering scheme shown in for all structures discussed.
elements.clean_text: To minimize problems with X-ray absorption, we carefully selected compounds that readily grow well-developed crystals, comprise atoms as light as possible, and have as small asymmetric units as possible. To emphasize the difference in electron delocalization, we will use the atom numbering scheme shown in  for all structures discussed.

elements.content: Atom numbering scheme used for the structures discussed. Bonds with delocalized π electrons are represented as dashed double lines. Labeling on the left is used for compounds I and II and the right one for compounds III, IV, and V.

elements.content: We have determined X-ray charge densities of the following compounds: chloranilic acid dihydrate (I), potassium chloranilate monohydrate (III), coordination polymer [Mn­(CA)­(H2O)] n (IV), and a mononuclear complex [Cu­(CA)2­(H2O)2]­Him2 (V, Him = imidazolium). In addition, we also consider previously published potassium hydrogen chloranilate dihydrate (II). To facilitate comparison, we use the atom numbering scheme shown in for all structures; in the case of centrosymmetric rings (in I, III and V), the adequate symmetry equivalence is indicated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

We have determined X-ray charge densities of the following compounds: chloranilic acid dihydrate (I), potassium chloranilate monohydrate (III), coordination polymer [Mn(CA)(H2O)] n  (IV), and a mononuclear complex [Cu(CA)2(H2O)2]Him2 (V, Him = imidazolium). In addition, we also consider previously published potassium hydrogen chloranilate dihydrate (II). To facilitate comparison, we use the atom numbering scheme shown in  for all structures; in the case of centrosymmetric rings (in I, III and V), the adequate symmetry equivalence is indicated.

elements.content: Bond orders and main parameters of electron density topology in the chloranilate moieties are given in and and ; more details can be found in the Supporting Information, Tables S1–S5 and Figures S16–S17. As can be seen from , our results confirm previously established structures (). Geometries of hydrogen chloranilate monoanion and chloranilate dianion (II and III) are consistent with and . Geometries of the coordinated species IV and V are also in agreement with and .

More details on topology of electron density are given in Figure and Tables S1–S5 in the Supporting Information. When the atoms are symmetry related, the operators are shown: (i) x, −y, −z; (ii) −x, −y, −z; (iii) 1/2 – x, 3 / 2 – y, 1 – z.

Atomic charges (; more details, including Bader charges are in the Supporting Information, Tables S6–S13) nicely illustrate stabilization of the anions by electron delocalization. After deprotonation, both oxygen atoms in the delocalized fragments O1–C1–C6–C5–O4 and O2–C2–C3–C4–O3 have a partial negative charge between −0.25 and −0.30 e. Inductive effect of the chlorine atoms is responsible for further stabilization: their charge increases from −0.11 in the neutral H2CA to −0.36 e in CA2– (). Thus, the effect of chlorine substitution is similar to the one observed in tetrachlorosemiquinone radical anions. In the coordinated species IV and V, there is no such effect, and more negative charge is located at the coordinating oxygen atoms, probably due to donation of electron density to the d orbitals of the metal cations. Accordingly, electron density and the corresponding bond orders of C–O bonds are significantly lower than in the noncoordinated species ().
elements.clean_text: Atomic charges (; more details, including Bader charges are in the Supporting Information, Tables S6-S13) nicely illustrate stabilization of the anions by electron delocalization. After deprotonation, both oxygen atoms in the delocalized fragments O1-C1-C6-C5-O4 and O2-C2-C3-C4-O3 have a partial negative charge between -0.25 and -0.30 e. Inductive effect of the chlorine atoms is responsible for further stabilization: their charge increases from -0.11 in the neutral H2CA to -0.36 e in CA2- (). Thus, the effect of chlorine substitution is similar to the one observed in tetrachlorosemiquinone radical anions. In the coordinated species IV and V, there is no such effect, and more negative charge is located at the coordinating oxygen atoms, probably due to donation of electron density to the d orbitals of the metal cations. Accordingly, electron density and the corresponding bond orders of C-O bonds are significantly lower than in the noncoordinated species ().

More details are given in Supporting Information, Tables S6–S13.

According to the topology of electron density (), metal–oxygen bonds can be characterized as intermediate cases between strongly polar and ionic. Mn–O bonds have significantly lower electron density (0.24–0.29 e·Å–3) than Cu–O (equatorial bonds: 0.36–0.42 e·Å–3), indicating more pronounced ionic character, as has been previously observed in different complexes. The apical Cu–O bond is elongated, and its maximum electron density is only 0.14 e·Å–3; thus it can be regarded as predominantly ionic.
elements.clean_text: According to the topology of electron density (), metal-oxygen bonds can be characterized as intermediate cases between strongly polar and ionic. Mn-O bonds have significantly lower electron density (0.24-0.29 e⋅Å-3) than Cu-O (equatorial bonds: 0.36-0.42 e⋅Å-3), indicating more pronounced ionic character, as has been previously observed in different complexes. The apical Cu-O bond is elongated, and its maximum electron density is only 0.14 e⋅Å-3; thus it can be regarded as predominantly ionic.

As an example of the neutral acid, we selected the well-known chloranilic acid dihydrate, H2CA·2H2O, which is more stable and forms better crystals than its anhydrous analogue; so it is more suited for a charge density study. The molecule has a crystallographic symmetry C i , and we will use atom numbering analogously to other structures ().
elements.clean_text:
Neutral Chloranilic Acid: p-Quinone (I)

As an example of the neutral acid, we selected the well-known chloranilic acid dihydrate, H2CA⋅2H2O, which is more stable and forms better crystals than its anhydrous analogue; so it is more suited for a charge density study. The molecule has a crystallographic symmetry C  i , and we will use atom numbering analogously to other structures ().

elements.content: Since neutral quinones lack delocalization of π electrons, distribution of electron density and electrostatic potential in the ring is not uniformly distributed. The electrostatic potential map of neutral chloranilic () reveals an expected excess of negative charge at the carbonyl oxygen atoms and a slight excess of electron density at the double bonds, whereas the single ones are electron-poor. According to the topology of electron density ( and S1), formally single bond C2–C3 (and its symmetry equivalent C5–C6) is stronger than C1–C2 (and its symmetry equivalent C4–C5): their respective bond orders are 0.94 and 0.89. This is in accord with molecular geometry: bond C2–C3 is by 0.057 Å shorter than C1–C2. Double bond C3–C4 (and its symmetry equivalent C6–C1) is slightly longer than average CC bonds (d = 1.299–1.331 Å), with a bond order of 1.54. The C–O bonds are more similar. The carbonyl bonds are slightly elongated with a bond order of 1.50 and have considerably lower ρcp electron density than formal double bonds. On the other hand, the hydroxyl C–O bonds are nearly 0.1 Å shorter than typical single bonds (in hydroquinones they are typically 1.38–1.40 Å long) with a bond order of 1.19. Accordingly, a weak electron delocalization in the conjugated system O1–C1–C6–C5–O4 and its symmetry equivalent, O2–C2–C3–C4–O3 was observed. These two systems are separated by a single C1–C2 bond. Chloranilic acid contains distinguishable formally single and double bonds as revealed by their geometrical parameters, electron density, and IR bands. Thus, one can conclude that the neutral chloranilic acid has indeed a structure of p-quinone as shown in .
elements.clean_text: Since neutral quinones lack delocalization of π electrons, distribution of electron density and electrostatic potential in the ring is not uniformly distributed. The electrostatic potential map of neutral chloranilic () reveals an expected excess of negative charge at the carbonyl oxygen atoms and a slight excess of electron density at the double bonds, whereas the single ones are electron-poor. According to the topology of electron density ( and S1), formally single bond C2-C3 (and its symmetry equivalent C5-C6) is stronger than C1-C2 (and its symmetry equivalent C4-C5): their respective bond orders are 0.94 and 0.89. This is in accord with molecular geometry: bond C2-C3 is by 0.057 Å shorter than C1-C2. Double bond C3-C4 (and its symmetry equivalent C6-C1) is slightly longer than average CC bonds (d = 1.299-1.331 Å), with a bond order of 1.54. The C-O bonds are more similar. The carbonyl bonds are slightly elongated with a bond order of 1.50 and have considerably lower ρcp electron density than formal double bonds. On the other hand, the hydroxyl C-O bonds are nearly 0.1 Å shorter than typical single bonds (in hydroquinones they are typically 1.38-1.40 Å long) with a bond order of 1.19. Accordingly, a weak electron delocalization in the conjugated system O1-C1-C6-C5-O4 and its symmetry equivalent, O2-C2-C3-C4-O3 was observed. These two systems are separated by a single C1-C2 bond. Chloranilic acid contains distinguishable formally single and double bonds as revealed by their geometrical parameters, electron density, and IR bands. Thus, one can conclude that the neutral chloranilic acid has indeed a structure of p-quinone as shown in .

elements.content: Multipolar experimental electrostatic potential mapped on electron density isosurface of 0.5 e·Å–3 for neutral chloranilic acid (I), hydrogen chloranilate monoanion, (II), chloranilate dianion (III), chloranilate moiety acting as a bridging (bis)­bidentate ligand (IV), and chloranilate moiety acting as a terminal bidentate ligand (V). Color scale: −0.1 (red) to +1 (dark blue) e·Å–1. Apical water molecules in IV and V have been removed for clarity.

elements.content:
A detailed charge density study of potassium hydrogen chloranilate dihydrate, KHCA·2H2O, has already been published, and we only provide data for comparison to other structures.

Electrostatic potential is shown in . Topology of electron density reveals two different halves of the molecule: the protonated fragment (O1–C1–C6–C5–O4) shows similarity with one-half of a neutral molecule, with distinguishable single and double bonds (, , and S2). On the other hand, the deprotonated fragment (O2–C2–C3–C4-O3) has a fully delocalized system with all bond orders between 1.33 and 1.59 (average about 1.50, and S2). The negative charge is delocalized throughout the fragment O2–C2–C3–C4–O3 ( and S7). The C1–C2 and symmetrically equivalent C4–C5 bonds are even weaker than in the neutral molecule since their orders are significantly lower than 1.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogen Chloranilate Monoanion (II)

A detailed charge density study of potassium hydrogen chloranilate dihydrate, KHCA⋅2H2O, has already been published, and we only provide data for comparison to other structures.

Electrostatic potential is shown in . Topology of electron density reveals two different halves of the molecule: the protonated fragment (O1-C1-C6-C5-O4) shows similarity with one-half of a neutral molecule, with distinguishable single and double bonds (, , and S2). On the other hand, the deprotonated fragment (O2-C2-C3-C4-O3) has a fully delocalized system with all bond orders between 1.33 and 1.59 (average about 1.50,  and S2). The negative charge is delocalized throughout the fragment O2-C2-C3-C4-O3 ( and S7). The C1-C2 and symmetrically equivalent C4-C5 bonds are even weaker than in the neutral molecule since their orders are significantly lower than 1.

elements.content:
Among several salts comprising chloranilate dianion tested, the best diffraction data were obtained from its potassium salt monohydrate, K2CA·H2O.

From electrostatic potential () and topology of electron density (, , and S3), it is evident that the chloranilate dianion comprises two fully delocalized π systems (O1–C1–C6–C5–O4 and O2–C2–C3–C4–O3, respectively) joined by two single bonds (). The two units of negative charge are also delocalized on the two pairs of oxygen atoms ( and S10). Since the dianion has a crystallographic symmetry C i , its two π systems are equivalent. It is interesting to note the descending electron density value and topological order of the single bonds C1–C2 and its symmetry equivalent C4–C5: They are strongest in the neutral molecule and the weakest in the dianion (bond orders of 0.89 and 0.76, respectively). Additional charge of the anions or perhaps enhanced electron delocalization apparently weakens these bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Chloranilate Dianion: Two Delocalized Systems Separated by Two Single Bonds (III)

Among several salts comprising chloranilate dianion tested, the best diffraction data were obtained from its potassium salt monohydrate, K2CA⋅H2O. 

From electrostatic potential () and topology of electron density (, , and S3), it is evident that the chloranilate dianion comprises two fully delocalized π systems (O1-C1-C6-C5-O4 and O2-C2-C3-C4-O3, respectively) joined by two single bonds (). The two units of negative charge are also delocalized on the two pairs of oxygen atoms ( and S10). Since the dianion has a crystallographic symmetry C  i , its two π systems are equivalent. It is interesting to note the descending electron density value and topological order of the single bonds C1-C2 and its symmetry equivalent C4-C5: They are strongest in the neutral molecule and the weakest in the dianion (bond orders of 0.89 and 0.76, respectively). Additional charge of the anions or perhaps enhanced electron delocalization apparently weakens these bonds.

elements.content: One of the simplest coordination polymers with bridging (bis)­bidentate chloranilate ligand is [Mn­(CA)­(H2O)] n . It comprises a centrosymmetric chloranilate ligand with a dianion-like structure: two fully delocalized π electron systems (O1–C1–C6–C5–O4 and symmetrically equivalent O2–C2–C3–C4–O3) separated by two single C–C bonds (C1–C2 and its symmetry equivalent C4–C5, with a bond order of 0.90; ). Four C–C bonds in the delocalized system are essentially equal, with orders of 1.53 and 1.56, while the four C–O have an order of 1.29 (, , and S4). The values obtained are in accord with IR spectra revealing a single C–O stretching vibration, only.
elements.clean_text:
Bridging (Bis)bidentate Ligand: Dianion-like (IV)

One of the simplest coordination polymers with bridging (bis)bidentate chloranilate ligand is [Mn(CA)(H2O)] n . It comprises a centrosymmetric chloranilate ligand with a dianion-like structure: two fully delocalized π electron systems (O1-C1-C6-C5-O4 and symmetrically equivalent O2-C2-C3-C4-O3) separated by two single C-C bonds (C1-C2 and its symmetry equivalent C4-C5, with a bond order of 0.90; ). Four C-C bonds in the delocalized system are essentially equal, with orders of 1.53 and 1.56, while the four C-O have an order of 1.29 (, , and S4). The values obtained are in accord with IR spectra revealing a single C-O stretching vibration, only.

elements.content: Compared to the uncoordinated dianion (III), C–O bonds are apparently weaker when in a complex ( and ), due to formation of coordination bonds, i.e., transfer of electron density from oxygen atoms toward the manganese center. However, some electron density is transferred to C–C bonds, which are considerably stronger than in III.
elements.clean_text: Compared to the uncoordinated dianion (III), C-O bonds are apparently weaker when in a complex ( and ), due to formation of coordination bonds, i.e., transfer of electron density from oxygen atoms toward the manganese center. However, some electron density is transferred to C-C bonds, which are considerably stronger than in III.

elements.content: To study chloranilate acting as a terminal bidentate ligand, the complex salt [Cu­(CA)2­(H2O)2]­Him2 (Him = imidazolium), recently described by us, was chosen, which comprises a centrosymmetric dianion [Cu­(CA)2­(H2O)2]2–. Molecular geometry () and IR spectrum suggest an o-quinoid form of the chloranilate moiety, but charge density data indicate that a small degree of electron delocalization is also present ( and S5, ). “Pure” single bonds C1–C2 and C4–C5, which do not take part in delocalization are severely electron-depleted and thus weakened (their bond orders are 0.64 and 0.55, respectively). The other two formally single bonds (C3–C4 and C5–C6) are in fact considerably stronger than typical single C–C bonds (respective bond orders of 1.18 and 1.17), while formally double bonds C2–C3 and C5–C6 are weaker (respective bond orders of 1.37 and 1.46). The difference between C–O bonds is less pronounced: those facing the metal are closer to single bonds (respective bond orders of 1.30 and 1.27), while the uncoordinated ones are stronger (bond orders of 1.38). This implies a partial electron delocalization in the O1–C1–C6–C5–O4 and O2–C2–C3–C4–O3 fragments. The electronic structure of the chloranilate acting as a terminal bidentate ligand thus shows a slight variation compared to an o-quinone structure.
elements.clean_text:
Terminal Bidentate Ligand: o-Quinone (V)

To study chloranilate acting as a terminal bidentate ligand, the complex salt [Cu(CA)2(H2O)2]Him2 (Him = imidazolium), recently described by us, was chosen, which comprises a centrosymmetric dianion [Cu(CA)2(H2O)2]2-. Molecular geometry () and IR spectrum suggest an o-quinoid form of the chloranilate moiety, but charge density data indicate that a small degree of electron delocalization is also present ( and S5, ). "Pure" single bonds C1-C2 and C4-C5, which do not take part in delocalization are severely electron-depleted and thus weakened (their bond orders are 0.64 and 0.55, respectively). The other two formally single bonds (C3-C4 and C5-C6) are in fact considerably stronger than typical single C-C bonds (respective bond orders of 1.18 and 1.17), while formally double bonds C2-C3 and C5-C6 are weaker (respective bond orders of 1.37 and 1.46). The difference between C-O bonds is less pronounced: those facing the metal are closer to single bonds (respective bond orders of 1.30 and 1.27), while the uncoordinated ones are stronger (bond orders of 1.38). This implies a partial electron delocalization in the O1-C1-C6-C5-O4 and O2-C2-C3-C4-O3 fragments. The electronic structure of the chloranilate acting as a terminal bidentate ligand thus shows a slight variation compared to an o-quinone structure.

elements.content: We confirmed by X-ray charge density and AIM analysis the expected structures of the five species of chloranilic acid: neutral molecule, mono- and dianion, and two complexation chelating modes: bridging (bis)­bidentate and terminal bidendate. The neutral chloranilic acid (I) has a p-quinoid structure with distinguishable single and double bonds and very little electron delocalization. Its monoanion (II) has π electrons delocalized over a half of the ring, while the other half has distinguishable single and double bonds. The dianion (III) has two delocalized fragments separated by two single bonds. The chloranilate moiety acting as a bridging (bis)­bidentate ligand (IV) also has a dianion-like structure. Acting as a terminal bidentate ligand (V), it has an o-quinone-like structure with a slight degree of electron delocalization; nevertheless, formally single and double bonds can be distinguished.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We confirmed by X-ray charge density and AIM analysis the expected structures of the five species of chloranilic acid: neutral molecule, mono- and dianion, and two complexation chelating modes: bridging (bis)bidentate and terminal bidendate. The neutral chloranilic acid (I) has a p-quinoid structure with distinguishable single and double bonds and very little electron delocalization. Its monoanion (II) has π electrons delocalized over a half of the ring, while the other half has distinguishable single and double bonds. The dianion (III) has two delocalized fragments separated by two single bonds. The chloranilate moiety acting as a bridging (bis)bidentate ligand (IV) also has a dianion-like structure. Acting as a terminal bidentate ligand (V), it has an o-quinone-like structure with a slight degree of electron delocalization; nevertheless, formally single and double bonds can be distinguished.

elements.content:
We have also quantitatively assessed the role of delocalization of the negative charge and inductive effect of chlorine substituents in stabilization of the anion.

It is interesting to note that simple Lewis-style diagrams shown in are in a good agreement with our structures obtained by AIM analysis of experimental charge density. Therefore, the Lewis model of chemical bonding, over 100 years old, is still valid and useful. The sophisticated modern methods merely corroborated it.
elements.clean_text:
We have also quantitatively assessed the role of delocalization of the negative charge and inductive effect of chlorine substituents in stabilization of the anion.

It is interesting to note that simple Lewis-style diagrams shown in  are in a good agreement with our structures obtained by AIM analysis of experimental charge density. Therefore, the Lewis model of chemical bonding, over 100 years old, is still valid and useful. The sophisticated modern methods merely corroborated it.

elements.content:
Chloranilic acid dihydrate was prepared by the original Graebe method and recrystallized from an aqueous solution. Other compounds were prepared by known procedures.

X-ray Diffraction and Multipolar Refinement

For all crystals, highly redundant diffraction data were collected to the maximum resolution of 0.50 Å.

X-ray diffraction measurements of compounds I and III were performed at 110 K on an Oxford Diffraction SuperNova diffractometer equipped with a microfocus Mo tube and CCD detector. CrysAlis PRO program package was used for data reduction and analytical absorption correction. The multiple integrated reflections were averaged for the appropriate space groups using SORTAV adapted to area detector data.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Preparation

Chloranilic acid dihydrate was prepared by the original Graebe method and recrystallized from an aqueous solution. Other compounds were prepared by known procedures. 

X-ray Diffraction and Multipolar Refinement

For all crystals, highly redundant diffraction data were collected to the maximum resolution of 0.50 Å.

X-ray diffraction measurements of compounds I and III were performed at 110 K on an Oxford Diffraction SuperNova diffractometer equipped with a microfocus Mo tube and CCD detector. CrysAlis PRO program package was used for data reduction and analytical absorption correction. The multiple integrated reflections were averaged for the appropriate space groups using SORTAV  adapted to area detector data.

elements.content: A single crystal of IV was measured at 100 K on an Oxford Rigaku XtaLab Synergy S diffractometer with a PhotonJet Mo source and HyPix pixel detector. CrysAlis PRO program package was used for data reduction and absorption correction. The multiple integrated reflections were averaged for the appropriate space groups using SORTAV adapted to area detector data.
elements.clean_text: A single crystal of IV was measured at 100 K on an Oxford Rigaku XtaLab Synergy S diffractometer with a PhotonJet Mo source and HyPix pixel detector. CrysAlis PRO program package was used for data reduction and absorption correction. The multiple integrated reflections were averaged for the appropriate space groups using SORTAV  adapted to area detector data.

elements.content: A single crystal of V was measured on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer at 100 K. Program package Bruker Apex was used for data reduction and analytical absorption correction. The multiple integrated reflections were averaged for the appropriate space groups using SORTAV adapted to area detector data.
elements.clean_text: A single crystal of V was measured on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer at 100 K. Program package Bruker Apex  was used for data reduction and analytical absorption correction. The multiple integrated reflections were averaged for the appropriate space groups using SORTAV  adapted to area detector data.

elements.content:
Spherical-atom models were refined using SHELXL-97; atomic coordinates were taken from the room-temperature structures.

For multipolar refinement (vs. F 2) the program package MoPro was used. Chlorine, copper, and manganese atoms were modeled up to the hexadecapole level, O, N, and C as octupolar, and hydrogen atoms with one dipole along the H–X bond direction. Vibrations of chlorine, copper, and manganese atoms were refined as anharmonic using third-order Gram-Charlier coefficients in IV and V and fourth-order Gram-Charlier coefficients in I and III. Anisotropic parameters for hydrogen atoms were calculated by the SHADE3 server and imported into the multipolar model (and constrained during the refinement); O–H distances were restrained to 0.967(2) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Spherical-atom models were refined using SHELXL-97; atomic coordinates were taken from the room-temperature structures. 

For multipolar refinement (vs. F 2) the program package MoPro  was used. Chlorine, copper, and manganese atoms were modeled up to the hexadecapole level, O, N, and C as octupolar, and hydrogen atoms with one dipole along the H-X bond direction. Vibrations of chlorine, copper, and manganese atoms were refined as anharmonic using third-order Gram-Charlier coefficients in IV and V and fourth-order Gram-Charlier coefficients in I and III. Anisotropic parameters for hydrogen atoms were calculated by the SHADE3 server and imported into the multipolar model (and constrained during the refinement); O-H distances were restrained to 0.967(2) Å.

elements.content:
Topological bond orders were calculated using the formula n topo = a + b λ 3 + c ( λ 1 + λ 2 ) + d ρ cp

Coefficients a, b, c, and d were taken from the literature: for C–C bonds a = −0.522, b = −1.695, c = 0.00, d = 8.473; for C–O bonds a = −0.427, b = −0.240, c = 0.280, d = 6.464; for O–H bonds and H···O hydrogen bonds a = 0.00, b = −0.10, c = 0.14, d = 3.32. ESDs of the charge density properties were estimated by the recently published method.
elements.clean_text:
Topological bond orders were calculated using the formula       n   topo   = a + b   λ   3   + c  (   λ   1   +   λ   2   )  + d   ρ   cp      

Coefficients a, b, c, and d were taken from the literature: for C-C bonds a = -0.522, b = -1.695, c = 0.00, d = 8.473; for C-O bonds a = -0.427, b = -0.240, c = 0.280, d = 6.464; for O-H bonds and H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds a = 0.00, b = -0.10, c = 0.14, d = 3.32. ESDs of the charge density properties were estimated by the recently published method.

elements.content: Geometry, charge density and electrostatic properties calculations were performed by MoPro; molecular graphics were prepared using MoProViewer and ORTEP-3. Crystallographic and refinement data are shown in ; additional details on refinement are deposited as Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: Geometry, charge density and electrostatic properties calculations were performed by MoPro; molecular graphics were prepared using MoProViewer  and ORTEP-3. Crystallographic and refinement data are shown in ; additional details on refinement are deposited as Supporting Information.

SHELXL weighting scheme: W(h,k,l) = 1/[s 2(Fo 2) + (a.P)2 + b.P] where P = (F o 2 + 2F c 2)/3.

We performed quantum calculations using the CRYSTAL17 software for periodic DFT. We utilized atomic coordinates after multipolar refinement with no further geometry optimization. Compounds were modeled on the B3LYP/6-31G­(d,p) theory level, using either the original Pople basis sets or basis sets modified for periodic DFT calculations when available. The only exception was the potassium atom, for which we used a modified pVTZ basis set since basis sets became linearly dependent when we introduced potassium 6-31G or 6-311G basis functions.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Chemical Calculations

We performed quantum calculations using the CRYSTAL17 software for periodic DFT. We utilized atomic coordinates after multipolar refinement with no further geometry optimization. Compounds were modeled on the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) theory level, using either the original Pople basis sets or basis sets modified for periodic DFT calculations when available. The only exception was the potassium atom, for which we used a modified pVTZ basis set since basis sets became linearly dependent when we introduced potassium 6-31G or 6-311G basis functions.

elements.content: Once CRYSTAL17 calculated the wave function, we used the Properties program to obtain structure factors. We refined multipolar parameters (i.e., everything but the scale factor, coordinates, and ADPs) against these structure factors in MoPro. We performed the same analyses on theoretical charge density for comparison with experimental results. Additionally, in order to obtain information on theoretical atomic charges in the studied compounds, we performed topological analysis of the periodic electron density adopting the QTAIM approach using the TOPOND14 program, integrated with CRYSTAL17.
elements.clean_text: Once CRYSTAL17 calculated the wave function, we used the Properties program to obtain structure factors. We refined multipolar parameters (i.e., everything but the scale factor, coordinates, and ADPs) against these structure factors in MoPro. We performed the same analyses on theoretical charge density for comparison with experimental results. Additionally, in order to obtain information on theoretical atomic charges in the studied compounds, we performed topological analysis of the periodic electron density adopting the QTAIM approach using the TOPOND14 program, integrated with CRYSTAL17.

Atomic Charges in the Five Forms of Chloranilic Acid Derived from Refined Population of Valence Shell (<italic>P</italic> <sub>val</sub>) Values<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="tbl3-fn1"></xref> I II III IV V C1 0.00(8) +0.07(7) –0.03(3) +0.06(5) +0.22(5) C2 –0.04(5) –0.10(9) –0.03(3) +0.06(8) +0.22(8) C3 +0.13(7) –0.23(7) +0.05(5) +0.10(7) –0.33(7) C4 0.00(8) i +0.16(7) –0.03(3) ii +0.06(5) iii +0.23(5) C5 –0.04(5) i –0.01(8) –0.03(3) ii +0.06(8) iii +0.23(8) C6 +0.13(7) i –0.13(7) +0.05(5) ii +0.10(7) iii –0.28(7) O1 –0.20(3) –0.27(6) –0.28(2) –0.17(3) –0.43(3) O2 –0.06(3) –0.17(5) –0.28(2) –0.265(3) –0.42(3) O3 –0.20(3) i –0.33(4) –0.28(2) ii –0.17(3) iii –0.35(3) O4 –0.06(3) i –0.14(4) –0.28(2) ii –0.265(3) iii –0.34(3) H1 +0.23(3) +0.33(6) H2 +0.23(3) i Cl1 –0.11(3) –0.09(3) –0.36(3) –0.06(3) –0.08(3) Cl2 –0.11(3) i –0.22(3) –0.36(3) ii –0.06(3) iii –0.08(3)

Atoms C4, C5, C6, O3, O4, H2, and Cl2 are symmetry equivalents of atoms C1, C2, C3, O1, O2, H1 and Cl1, respectively, in compounds I, III, and IV, obtained with the following symmetry operators: (i) x, −y, −z; (ii) −x, −y, −z; (iii) 1/2 – x, 3 / 2 – y, 1 – z. More details are given in Supporting Information, Tables S6–S13.
